title: Grade 5 Forces and Mechanisms Terms Set 2

questions.definition: A basic mechanical device that makes work easier by changing the direction or magnitude of a force. Example: A lever or an inclined plane.
A simple machine where a wheel is attached to a central rod, allowing easier movement of objects. Example: A rolling cart uses this system.
A triangular tool used to split, cut, or lift objects. Example: An axe blade is a wedge.
A simple machine consisting of a twisted inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder. Example: A jar lid uses this mechanism.
The part of a lever that extends from the fulcrum to where the force is applied. Example: The long handle of a crowbar.
The ratio of output force to input force in a mechanical system. Example: A pulley system can provide a high mechanical advantage.
The fixed point on which a lever pivots. Example: The center of a seesaw acts as its fulcrum.
The object or weight that a machine is designed to move or support. Example: The weight placed on a pulley.
The force applied to a simple machine to do work. Example: The force you use to push a wheelbarrow.
The force exerted by a machine to move a load. Example: The force a car jack uses to lift a vehicle.
The energy stored in an object when it is stretched or compressed. Example: A stretched rubber band.
The force that resists motion when two surfaces are in contact. Example: Friction between your shoes and the ground prevents slipping.
The force that opposes the motion of objects moving through air. Example: A parachute uses air resistance to slow descent.
The ability of a structure to remain balanced and resist tipping or collapsing. Example: A triangle is often used in bridges for stability.
When two forces acting on an object are equal in size but opposite in direction. Example: A book resting on a table experiences balanced forces.
When forces acting on an object are not equal, causing the object to move or change direction. Example: Pushing a chair across a room.
The point where an object's mass is evenly distributed in all directions. Example: Balancing a ruler on your finger shows its center of gravity.
The forces or weights that a structure must support. Example: A bridge holds both its own weight and the cars traveling on it.
A long, rigid structural element that supports loads. Example: Steel beams are used in building skyscrapers.
The resistance of a material to being stretched or pulled apart. Example: A steel cable has high tensile strength.
A force that squeezes or presses an object. Example: The pressure on a chair leg when someone sits on it.
A force that causes parts of a material to slide past one another in opposite directions. Example: Scissors create shear force when cutting paper.
The internal force per unit area within a material, caused by external forces. Example: Stress on a bridge increases during heavy traffic.
A change in the shape of an object due to stress. Example: A bent metal rod under extreme force.
The route through which loads are transferred in a structure. Example: In a skyscraper, loads travel down columns to the foundation.
